habitat_description:
The distribution of this species is restricted to the Guadalupe River system of south and central Texas (Killebrew et al. 2002). In this area, this species occupies creeks, low gradient rivers and streams, and shallow water pools and riffles. It is also commonly found in riparian zones such as forested wetland. This species is known to burrow in or using soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter (Natureserve.org). Suitable habitat includes rivers with shallow depths, muddy, with moderate flow, silty and gravelly substrates (Ernst et al. 1994). Preferred optimal habitat is characterized by both riffles and pools because of insect prey availability (USFWS 1993). Basking sites include brush piles, logs, rocks, cypress knees, and fallen shrubs and trees. The only time this species visits land is during nesting (Ernst et al. 1994; USFWS 1993).

*Map turtles live in riverine-riparian systems and associated floodplain lakes, ponds, and sloughs. Often they nest on sandy banks or sand bars but sometimes up to about 100 m from water (Natureserve.org)
